newsitem.title: FRANCE: FOCUS-Socialists to mull France Telecom.
newsitem.headline: FOCUS-Socialists to mull France Telecom.

text.p: France's Socialist Party, staking out its position as the new left-wing government considers whether to sell a minority stake in France Telecom, said on Thursday the group should remain under state control.

"We said during the (election) campaign we want a French telecommunications company which remains a public company because it is a public service," Francois Hollande, the interim Socialist party secretary, told France Inter radio.
The government did not discuss the issue of France Telecom in its first full meeting on Thursday chaired by Gaullist centre-right President Jacques Chirac, a spokeswoman said.
If the centre-right had won the legislative election, the sale of 30 to 35 percent of France Telecom, possibly the biggest French stock market operation, would have started today.

"On specific dossiers it is a question for the ministers in charge," government spokeswoman Catherine Trautmann said after the cabinet meeting. "The prime minister's intention is not to be rushed into anything," she added.
The issue of the sale of shares in France Telecom lies in the hands of Finance, Economy and Industry Minister Dominique Strauss-Kahn.
A co-writer of the Socialist election manifesto, Strauss-Kahn -- called "DSK" by his entourage -- opposes full privatisation.
He told Reuters in the run-up to the election that he was in favour of interaction between the private and public sectors.
Known as a pragmatic man, financial analysts expect him to press for the sale of a minority stake in the telecoms operator following a planned audit of France's public finances.
Newspaper reports suggest that there might be a budget shortfall of 25 to 50 billion francs ($4.3 to $8.6 billion).
France cannot use the proceeds of a France Telecom sale to plug this hole to meet the criteria for European economic and monetary union (EMU). But it can use the proceeds to finance other projects.

Former Finance Minister Jean Arthuis, who planned to sell France Telecom shares to raise 30 to 50 billion francs, wanted to use the money to refinance troubled state-companies such as bank Credit Lyonnais, insurer GAN or consumer electronics group Thomson Multimedia.

"Strauss-Kahn will want to use the money but he cannot be seen as reneging on the election promises. I think they will tell people they have found a big hole in the budget and that if they don't sell some of France Telecom, they can't carry out some of their job-creation plans," said a telecommunications analyst who did not want to be named.
He expected a sale to take place from September.
At France Telecom there was no comment on Thursday on whether chairman Michel Bon would seek talks with Strauss-Kahn to discuss the sale of a stake.

Bon told staff on Tuesday that the sale had effectively been suspended until the government took a decision. He said this was a setback but not a catastrophe and urged the company's 164,000 workforce to focus on the challenge of full competition in 1998.
Prime Minister Lionel Jospin said during the campaign he wanted to consult France Telecom staff before making a decision.

The CGC white-collar staff union said on Wednesday the sale was unavoidable, while leaders of three labour unions -- the CFTC, Force Ouvriere and CFDT -- said on Tuesday they would give qualified backing to a partial privatisation.
The Communist-led CGT and ultra-left Sud, the two largest unions at France Telecom, remain opposed. ($ = 5.825 French Francs)
